SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The experience for yourself, or someone else in your family, is not sufficient space to answer the questions. This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1911, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What I'd Tell Canadian Pioneers If I Knew It All," is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Western Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 2, entitled "Pioneer Life: What I'd Tell Canadian Pioneers If I Knew It All," is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 3, entitled "Pioneer Life: What I'd Tell Canadian Pioneers If I Knew It All," is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of our Provincial Archives. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

A WORD OF EXPLANATION TO THE PERSON ANSWERING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to respond to a general questionnaire on pioneer life, because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer. So don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The questionaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1942, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for separate questionnaires.

Other Questionnaires

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Richard Metheral
2. Your address: 735 Broadway Ave., Saskatoon
3. Date: Oct. 9, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Elizabethville, Town of Hope, Durham County, Ontario
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Richard Metheral, farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March 20, 1899
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - Madill's Corner, near Dunedin, Simcoe County, Ont.
     from 1869 to 1899
   - To Indian Head
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.). I was 33 years old when I came to Indian Head
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - Too little opportunity around old home
   - Member of a large family, 4 brothers & sisters
   - Land and too little land for all to live on. Land was not very productive (rocky and depleted of fertility)
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    Learned about West through neighbors who had come out to Indian Head in the 80's from near Creemore, Stayner and Dunedin
    Ben Holden (Collingwood) Tom Smith (Glen Huron) William Stephens (Collingwood)
    who had come to Indian Head were close friends of my father Holden and Stephens were in the Wide Awake district north of Indian Head. Even the Experimental Farm was well established then.
Richard Methera
Suite 1, Eaton Bldg.,
735 Broadway, Saskatoon.

1. Your full name: Richard Methera
2. Your address: 735 Broadway Ave., Saskatoon
3. Date: Oct. 9, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Elizabethville, Town of Hope, Durham County, Ontario
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Richard Methera, farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March 26, 1899
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - Madill's Corner, near Dunedin, Simcoe County, Ont.
   - From 1869 to 1899
8. How old were you when you first came to Eastern Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - Too little opportunity around old home
   - Member of a large family, 4 brothers & sisters
   - Too little land for all to live on. Land was not very productive (rocky and depleted of fertility)
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information).
    - Learned about West through neighbors who had come out to Indian Head in the 80's from near Creemore, Stayner and Dunedin
    - Ben Holden (Collingwood), Tim Smith (Glen Huron), William Stephens (Collingwood) who had come to Indian Head were close friends of my father. Holden and Stephens were in the Wide Awake district north of Indian Head. Even the Experimental Farm was well established then.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Most of them thought I was very foolish.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I came in a party to Indian Head with Stewart Jas. Creighton, Wm. Perry, Wes. Prentice and Helen Trew.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Came by rail to Indian Head March 26, 1899. Drove by horses & wagon to Weyburn the 76 miles across country.

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

In 1900 when I shipped settlers effects West when we switched a car of Napinka, Manitoba there were 11 cars of settlers effects going to Yellow Grass. Robt. Smith, Robt. Jacques, Jeffrey Jacques and William Bovair were on this train all going to Yellow Grass. They came from Collingwood, Golen Huron and Creemore in Simcoe County, Ontario.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I took a job with and worked for John Mitchell at Weyburn — brought his settlers effects from the head across to Weyburn in 1899.

At Yellow Grass SE sec. 12 twp. 11 rge. 17 w.r.

16. How did you settle or take up land?

Filed on sec. 12 Aug. 22, 1899.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I moved to Saskatoon in Sept., 1929 after having resided continuously for over 30 years at Yellow Grass.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Worked on farms around Dundin, Glen Huron and Smithdale (2 miles from Glenburn). Ploughing with a sidehill plough in summer and cutting hauled wood in winter time to Collingwood & Creemore.

After coming West I made my living growing wheat and raising livestock (principally grain growing).
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Most of them thought I was very foolish.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I came in a party to Indian Head with Stewart Jas.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Came by rail to Indian Head March 26, 1899

Drove by horses & wagon to Weyburn

the 76 miles across country

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

In 1900 when I shipped settlers effects West when we switched a car of Napinka, Manitoba there were 11 cars of settlers effects going to Yellow Grass.

Robt. Smith, Robt. Jacques, Jeffrey Jacques and William Bovair were on this train all young to Yellow Grass. They came from Collingwood Glen Huron and Creemore in Simcoe County, Ontario.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I took a job with and worked for John Mitchell at Weyburn — brought his settlers effects from the head across to Weyburn in 1899.

At Yellow Grass SE sec. 12 + N1/2 sec. 17 W.R.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Filed on sec. 12 Aug. 28, 1899

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I moved to Sas Katoon in Sept., 1929 after having resided continuously for over 30 years at Yellow Grass.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Worked on farms around Doreen, Glen Huron and Smithdale (2 miles from Glenburn). Ploughing with a side-hill plough in summer and cut & hauled wood in winter time to Collingwood & Creemore.

After coming West I made my living growing wheat and raising livestock (primarily grain raising)
About once every two weeks we had a daily train service on Soo Line running from Duluth to Toronto.

My nephew Joe Howard came along with my sisters effects. He filed on the same section we did in 1919 and we moved there in 1922. My brother-in-law E.C. Gosnell homesteaded at Tompkins, Sask.

In these particular experiences of pioneer days that makes me feel very grateful that I was able to be part of it.
19. How often did you write to relations or friends in your old home?

About once every two weeks. We had a daily train service on Sea Line route.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

I was married to Annie Gosnell at Dutton, Ontario Feb 26, 1902.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation of us as a place to settle?

My nephew Joe Howard came along with my settler's effects. He filed on the same section no. 12-11-17 W4 in 1899 and we got our patents in 1902. My brother-in-law Joe Howard came out later (believe in 1904).

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My brother Joe came out in 1910. My father-in-law, mother-in-law, etc. came out in 1890 and settled miles north of Weyburn purchasing a half section of land. A brother-in-law E.C. Gosnell homesteaded at Tompkins, Sask.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
25. When was the first car used in the community? First car was used in 1916 by Mr. Tugwell.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? I bought my car in 1914.

27. How did you travel before you had a car? I did not get a car until 1917 because I had a good horse.

28. Did you consider taking drivers tests? No, I did not take any tests.

29. Yellow Grass was 10 miles from Stoughton, Ontario. How far from your home?

30. How many people in your district traveled regularly on Saturdays? Usually only two or three people traveled on Saturdays.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? We never did very much business by mail order catalogue since we had two stores and three good stores in Yellow Grass and they had to have a livelihood. I felt you couldn't build a local community on mail order catalogues. After all Yellow Grass had one of the best football teams in Sask. 1905 and our lacrosse team of 1911-12 was tops. Good football and lacrosse players had to eat.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? Yellow Grass Rural Telephone Company established in 1907.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? I definitely decided I would stay when I shipped my settlers effects West.

We never did very much business by mail order catalogue since we had three good stores in Yellow Grass and they had to have a livelihood. I felt you couldn't build a local community on mail order catalogues. After all Yellow Grass had one of the best football teams in Sask. 1905 and our lacrosse team of 1911-12.

I definitely decided I would stay when I shipped my settlers effects West.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

A few settlers homesteaded & proved up, sold land, moved further west to get more land for their families but the majority were well satisfied with this community.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many remain?

Very few people left who lived northward east of Yellow Grass. Those who left were people on the "burnouts" southwest of Yellow Grass. These areas formed into P.E.R.A. pasture.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I joined the Canadian Order of Foresters at Singhampton in 1893 and for past 60 years have been an active member.

Got my 50 year pin in 1943 before 2nd World War.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first to have" or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates whenever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first name was given; (5) date and reason for change.

Lemon Lake NW 1/4 12-11-17 2nd Mer. was named after Mr. Lot Geo. Lemon who homesesteaded the NW 1/4 12-11-17 Oct 22, 1898 and was issued his patent to this quarter Nov 25, 1902. He was ranching here in the nineties when settlers started coming in and taking up land.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1943? What reasons did they have for moving?

A few settlers homesteaded & proved up, sold and moved further west to get more land for their families but the majority were well satisfied with this community; the people and the farming areas had the best of land.

Very few people left who lived north and east of Yellow Grass. Those who left were people on the "turnouts" southwest of Yellow Grass. This area formed into F.F.R.A. pasture.

35. Did you or some member of your family have held public office or have been active in any organization, union, etc., during the 1930s?

I joined the Canadian Order of Foresters at Southampton in 1893 and for past 60 years have been an active member.

Got my 50 year pin in 1943.

36. If you or any of your family or friends were interested in politics, [such as] Sasakatoon. I only once sought Public Office.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were interested in politics, [such as] Sasakatoon. I only once sought Public Office.
